12.97.text: Hi my name's Lilly and I want to be a ballerina.

19.84.text: (Sharee) I don't think there are a lot of things that could stand in the way and stop her to be honest...

22.84.text:
...she's a bit too mouthy.
(Pete) Very determined.

31.96.text:
(Director) Who are you?
(Lilly) Superstar Princess Lilly!

38.29.text:
(Director) What's it like having this film crew in here?
(Lilly) Strange! Argghh!!

48.47.text: This is the way to my bedroom and this is how I open the door.

56.87.text: (Sharee) Lilly is full on and she's very passionate about things.

61.81.text:
(Lilly) This is my bathroom and what I like about my 
bathroom is my pink curtain.

68.69.text:
(Sharee) Lilly's got a thing about "pink."
(Pete) She likes "bling bling."

71.72.text: Anything pink and sparkly, yes definitely.

82.49.text:
(Sharee) For Lilly, her Arthrogryposis she has in all four limbs. 
So her hands face the wrong way...

88.56.text: ...her elbows are stiff and her shoulders are rotated forward.

93.14.text:
I can get up to my bed by coming through here. 
You guys can squeeze through if you want too.

102.26.text:
(Sharee) Her hips don't work, so when she walks she has to 
walk through her hips rather...

105.67.text: ...than swing her legs, and she can't bring her legs together on her own.

115.02.text: (Sharee) She much prefers to be on her bottom on the floor, she knuckles her hands and moves herself around because it's quicker.

121.12.text:
She's 24.5kgs now, so the damage she can do to her shoulders 
is getting to more noticeable.

129.37.text: And this step is a bit wobbly.

135.26.text: (Sharee) Lilly doesn't like using prosthetics, they feel uncomfortable and they're really slow.

142.38.text:
(Sharee) For me, I find that frustrating it she doesn't 
want to use her legs.

147.62.text: And I'm thinking but you'd be so much better if you could use your legs.

151.52.text: And she's going, yeah but I don't want to use my legs. I just want to stay on my bottom and shuffle all day.

155.27.text: (Director) And what's your favorite way of getting around?

157.87.text:
(Lilly) Crawling and moving on my bottom.
They're both the best.

167.38.text: Because they're a bit easier than walking.

172.12.text:
Rosie normally falls asleep when I lay her down, so I'll just 
sit her up so she stays awake.

178.67.text: Guys, just tell me if she wakes up.

194.36.text: (Sharee) Lilly came into our lives when she was eight months old.

202.97.text: Her mum and dad were in a place where they couldn't look after her...

205.58.text: ...so we took on full day to day care and guardianship of Lilly.

210.57.text: And that was a change in plans.

215.31.text:
My youngest is 23, so we'd had a different life for us planned 
once my last one left home.

227.24.text:
So this is all new again, back to being single income and 
supporting a child.

232.11.text:
And doing all the mummy things, the nappies, 
the night bottles and stuff.

241.22.text: When Lilly was first born, she looked wrong.

248.80.text:
Her arms and legs were all on different angles 
where they shouldn't have been.

255.05.text: I went to visit and I noticed there was something wrong.

258.55.text: I did say something and the mid wife said she was going to be fine.

261.19.text:
That she was just in the birth canal too long and 
that she would come right.

267.61.text: It wasn't until she was three months old that she was taken to a doctor and diagnosed with Arthrogryposis.

280.46.text: (Sharee) We had no expectations at all. We were just winging it because we didn't know what Arthrogryposis was.

289.84.text: It was a really long learning curve; we did some Internet research on it.

294.36.text: We met up with a group with Arthrogryposis and they were amazing...

300.54.text:
and took us through everything that we needed to know 
and were there all the way.

309.15.text:
We knew that it was just an umbrella term to 
cover a whole range of things.

313.22.text: In each case we'd seen their condition was different...

317.62.text: so we haven't seen anyone like Lilly who has it in both arms and legs...

323.45.text: and who was stopped from doing most things because of that.

339.16.text:
Every time we changed her nappy, or she 
was lying down drinking a bottle...

342.95.text:
we would try and stretch out her limbs to try and 
stop some of the tightening that was going on.

357.67.text:
But what was happening was that the tightening was ongoing, 
so at some point...

361.90.text:
she would have to have surgery because the limbs 
were going to tighten...

365.84.text:
to the point where her heels would be on her bottom 
and she wouldn't even be able to sit.

379.07.text:
At that point it was already too late and the 
legs and the arms were too set...

383.29.text: and it was only down to physio. And the amount of physio that they said she would need would be eight hours a day.

394.11.text: So we had the first surgery on October 2nd just before she turned five.

399.32.text:
So hours in surgery and they cut through the top of the foot 
and pulled the foot around...

404.19.text:
and straightened it up. And six weeks after that the blood vessels 
had been so badly damaged...

410.34.text: during the surgery that the foot died.

418.11.text: First amputation that had to probably be the hardest because we weren't thinking of amputation at that point...

424.13.text: we were just thinking antibiotics fixing it and it would be okay.

429.52.text: So that was what was really, really hard.

442.28.text:
Having to watch her come out of surgery and see that 
she'd lost her leg - that was really hard.

450.15.text:
She just said, "Mummy why did you let them cut my foot off 
and throw it in the rubbish bin?"

455.31.text: And you can't tell her that.

477.76.text:
(Sharee) We'd always been really honest with Lilly 
and we told her every time...

480.43.text:
when we went into surgery what was going to happen... 
(Pete) ...and what the outcome would be.

487.10.text: So she knew that if she had the legs removed then she would be able to get new legs and still walk.

494.15.text: That was her goal - that was all she wanted to do - she wants to dance.

506.98.text:
Would you like to show me your new legs?
Shall we get out of here and try them on?

513.94.text:
(Sharee) When she first got them they had these big "duck feet" 
on the bottom of them...

518.27.text: and she goes, "Nah they're not my feet."

521.05.text: And she was disappointed because they didn't look like legs.

526.33.text: And she didn't want to use them, she didn't like them at all.

528.48.text: They were bulky, they were horrible, and they hurt.

543.23.text:
Well done. Can you get up on your legs?
(Lilly) Nope.

548.50.text:
Is is hard is it?
(Lilly) A bit hard getting up.

558.19.text:
(Sharee) Having to learn to walk with legs that aren't yours - 
that's really hard work.

567.22.text: (Sharee) And she has Lumbar Lordosis, so her back curves in...

569.91.text:
and you'll see when she stands that she stands arched. 
And it's about teaching her...

574.83.text:
to use her core tummy muscles and bringing in 
her bottom to stand straight.

578.98.text:
And once she can start doing that she'll start to get her own 
center of gravity a bit better.

591.88.text: Tummy in...you're doing that beautifully today.

644.00.text: (Sharee) It's her second year of school. She's spend a lot more time at school this year than she did last year...

655.80.text:
I'm really proud of how well she's done considering how 
much time she spent in hospital

659.31.text:
and how much pain she's been in, she's managed to keep up 
with all the other kids in class.

665.08.text:
(Girl) One time when I was on a boat, I caught a snapper and 
it pulled me into the water.

677.56.text: (Lilly) Once I was on a boat and the boat cracked in half and it tipped upside down and I was glued onto it. (Laughs)

702.10.text:
(Sharee) One of the biggest challenges that Lilly has at 
school during lunchtime...

705.83.text:
and playtime she stays in her wheelchair. 
There's nothing else for her to do.

715.19.text:
All the other kids are running around the playground, 
and she can't do that.

721.27.text:
Running in and out of the sandpit, they're running around 
chasing each other...

724.33.text:
but when she joins in they run fast and she can't keep up, 
so she gets bored and wonders around.

736.05.text:
This is where I need her to walk so that she can be 
out there and be mobile...

739.21.text:
and be in amongst all her friends. And even 
if she can't climb the jungle gym...

742.81.text:
she can still be at the bottom, cheering them on. And at this point 
she can't even get near the jungle gyms.

752.01.text: So Lilly is using her legs at the moment everyday at school...

754.82.text:
she's got an awesome teacher aide there called Caroline, 
who puts her through her paces.

765.68.text:
She walks from the toilet block to the library on 
her own with her walker in her legs...

771.06.text: which takes 33 minutes - it's a ten second walk for the average person.

783.82.text: On an average day for Lilly, 10-20 minutes in her legs is tiring.

792.85.text:
They reckon that ten minutes using prosthetics is the same as a 
normal person doing a quarter mile run.

808.13.text:
(Lilly) I'm sweating.
(Caroline) Do you want a drink?

811.61.text: (Lilly) No I want my legs off.

826.31.text:
(Lilly) Can we take my legs off right here?
(Caroline) Yes.

843.63.text: When I first stand up on my legs, I cried a little because it hurt.

891.89.text: (Sharee) As the week goes by and we get to Thursday and Friday...

895.15.text:
we notice the anger starts - a lot of anger. She's really 
aggressive and she yells and screams.

908.20.text:
At the end of last year she was so aggressive, 
and it was every single day...

912.18.text:
and it was lasting two or three hours that 
she was yelling and screaming...

914.87.text: and trying to hit and carry on.

917.05.text:
(Lilly) No I'm not touching you!!
(Sharee) What do you want to do then?

921.84.text:
(Lilly) Do my own thing and do what I want!
And I won't bother about listening to you again!

932.33.text:
(Sharee) It comes down to the grieving process. 
She's had dozens of surgeries...

937.55.text:
and so much invasive stuff done to her that it was 
almost overloading her system.

943.45.text: And it was control - she needed some piece of control in her life.

946.41.text:
(Lilly) I want everybody out! 
And I'm letting no one in here!

960.74.text: (Lilly) I don't want to sit on your knee!

974.60.text: (Sharee) Everything she does is physically draining for her.

978.91.text: But 99% of the time she's really positive about everything she does.

983.79.text: Everything she does is done to the best of her ability.

989.74.text: (Lilly) Daddy can you please put me up at the table?

992.82.text:
(Pete) I can are you ready for dinner?
(Lilly) Yep.

996.64.text: (Sharee) She needs to be independent, I think that's a big thing.

999.39.text:
And there's nothing wrong with her brain, so there's 
no reason why she can't...

1002.26.text: figure things out and do things herself and find a way to do things.

1005.33.text: (Sharee) Are you going to have any salad?

1008.05.text: (Lilly) No thank you, because I don't like salad.

1011.20.text: (Sharee) We got tired of feeding her because her arms use to be straight and her hands face backwards...

1015.11.text:
and we just got tired of feeding her all the time. 
And we said to her one day...

1019.69.text:
(Lilly) Salad tastes like rotten tomatoes.
(Pete) It will put hairs on your chest.

1032.68.text:
(Sharee) Pete built a tray that holds her plate because 
she needs to rest on the side...

1037.07.text:
and if she rests on the side then her plate will 
flip over, so he built a tray.

1040.49.text:
And put the plate in there, and she can rest on that.
And she can feed herself.

1043.32.text: And she taught herself to feed herself out of necessity.

1047.37.text: (Sharee) Hey Lilly, look at this cool book I found to read you.

1050.10.text:
(Lilly) Cool did you buy it?
(Sharee) I did, it says, "All tutus should be...

1058.44.text:
(Sharee) "I love my little tutu, it's..."
(Lilly) Pink!!

1064.06.text:
(Lilly) I'll say all the "pink" okay?
(Sharee) Okay.

1072.86.text:
(Sharee) "Our favorite person is our dance teacher...
she use to be a famous...

1083.80.text:
(Sharee) "We want to grow up to be famous..."
(Lilly) Pink!

1087.66.text:
(Sharee) "...tutu dancers too. But I think we would wear our tutus 
even if we were truck drivers."

1107.67.text: (Sharee) Recently she had a really bad dream that woke her twice.

1110.45.text: And in that dream, everything in her room was running away from her...

1112.58.text: and she couldn't catch up and she was really scared because nothing in her room was still but moving away from her.

1122.16.text:
She said to me, "Mummy but I had a dream catcher, 
why didn't it catch my dreams?"

1126.34.text: I said, "Because a dream catcher only catches bad dreams, and maybe your dream was trying to tell you something."

1131.43.text:
"Maybe you need to start walking now so you 
can catch up to these things."

1135.20.text: So now she wants to get up and start walking because her dream has told her that this is what she should be doing now.

1152.13.text:
Today I'm horse riding at the Horse Park, and if 
someone picks me a dirty horse...

1162.36.text: I can magic it into a pretty horse with my magic wand.

1171.57.text:
It would be really cool if I fell off and I was still 
holding onto the reins (laughs).

1185.70.text:
Hi Lilly, welcome to RDA. How are you?
(Lilly) Good.

1191.50.text: You're going to be riding Atlas, he's a very cute pony.

1200.97.text: Oh my goodness you're fast Lilly.

1211.09.text: Now she's learning to walk her balance is improving.

1215.73.text: And again, that's something riding can help with.

1226.96.text:
We're looking at building core strength, and making a fun activity, 
which builds confidence.

1232.41.text: And to give her the feeling of freedom of being on a horse because that's really important.

1236.64.text:
And looking down on everyone instead of always 
looking up, which is huge.

1246.48.text:
(Lilly) Can we do jumps?
(Lady) Can you stretch out the front?

1258.87.text: (Lilly) You nearly stepped in the poos.

1285.97.text:
(Sharee) We're going to meet Robbie and Jackie, 
and Robbie is missing one leg as well.

1291.77.text:
So it's going to be really good for Lilly to meet her and 
a female that she can talk to about that.

1307.10.text:
(Robbie) Hello you must be Lilly?
(Lilly) Hi.

1313.01.text:
(Robbie) This is my mum Jackie.
(Jackie) Hello we're delighted to have you in our house.

1328.13.text:
(Robbie) Do you know what these are?
(Lilly) That's what I'm going to get when I get my legs.

1333.01.text: (Robbie) Exactly, and do you know who these belong to?

1337.31.text:
(Robbie) So this leg here this is the last leg that I had 
before I had a huge operation...

1345.66.text:
like the operation that you've had. So when I was little 
I was born with a leg down to here.

1353.37.text:
But it wasn't a very good leg, and so when I was 12, 
they cut it off through the knee.

1360.13.text:
This is my first ever leg.
(Lilly) That you had when you were a baby?

1363.79.text:
(Robbie) Yeah do you want to touch it?
(Lilly) Yeah.

1368.70.text: (Robbie) And do you know what my leg is called?

1374.18.text: And this is Lucy, and this is Lucy, and they're all called Lucy.

1382.25.text: (Robbie) Well, it was really difficult for me to say, "Prosthesis" or "Artificial Leg" when I was little...

1389.99.text:
so we called it "Lucy Leg." This one has pink 
painted toes can you see?

1402.15.text: (Sharee) She's recently had a big blow out, everything came out...

1405.98.text: "I don't want to be me, I don't want to be somebody in a wheelchair..."

1410.16.text:
"I don't want people to stare at me, I want to be able to dance, 
I want to be able to swim...

1413.69.text:
and play on the jungle gyms with the kids at school, 
and I don't want to spend all day...

1417.66.text:
sitting in my wheels." Yeah it was just so much...
she suddenly realized who she was, you know.

1425.39.text:
(Jackie) It was about this age and it was the realization that 
how I am is not how everybody else is.

1430.45.text:
And she use to say, "Mum is my little leg going to grow 
like the other one?"

1437.20.text:
And I'd say, "Of yes it will grow, but it might not grow 
as much as the one on the right."

1443.64.text: And so she'd digest and ponder that and then about six weeks later...

1447.62.text:
we'd go through it all over again. And then we went 
through another season...

1451.93.text:
where Robbie decided herself, "What the heck," 
and her prosthetic was fluorescent pink...

1461.21.text: when she was a chapel Prefect at her school, with a crucifix because she tattooed with pen down the side of it.

1470.22.text:
So she thought what the heck if I'm going to then why not - 
here I am world I'm coming!

1475.77.text:
(Robbie) Does it feel real to you?
(Lilly) Kind of.

1479.54.text:
(Robbie) I want to ask you about your duck feet, can you 
tell me about your duck feet?

1483.07.text:
(Lilly) Well, if I bring them in I could show you.
(Robbie) And do you want to use them more?

1488.79.text:
(Lilly) No.
(Robbie) What about at school or at high school?

1495.14.text:
How will you get around then?
(Lilly) Do this all the time.

1499.19.text: (Robbie) Are you going to go round on your bottom all the time?

1504.11.text:
(Lilly) I can't when I got to high school because there are a lot 
of stairs that I'll have to get up.

1509.65.text: (Robbie) So what could you use a leg like this for?

1514.44.text:
(Lilly) Walking.
(Robbie) Would you be tall or short?

1523.53.text:
(Lilly) The same as you.
(Robbie) And what about dance - do you like dancing? 
What's your favorite type of dancing?

1538.75.text:
(Robbie) Do you know what we're going to do this afternoon? 
We're going to go and meet some real ballerinas.

1564.30.text:
(Lilly) They're going to be so jealous when they see my dress eh?
(Robbie) Yeah

1573.26.text:
(Lucy) Hello is it Lilly?
Hi Lilly I'm Lucy.

1577.93.text: (Lucy) Have you seen any ballet before on TV or anything like that?

1581.60.text:
(Lilly) I only have a DVD of ballet and that's all.
(Lucy) Oh really that's cool.

1587.23.text:
(Lilly) I said, Mum you'll have to put me in ballet at my school. 
She has too!

1599.40.text: (Sharee) We thought it would be really cool to take Lilly to a ballet class and watch the dancers do their practice.

1604.24.text:
We're hoping that it would inspire her and push her along to see 
the need for her to be walking...

1610.38.text: on her duck feet and then further along up to bigger legs.

1613.62.text:
(Lilly) I can do a spin.
(Lucy) You can do a spin can you?

1622.16.text: (Lucy) Wow, that's amazing it's so beautiful.

1626.88.text:
(Sharee) My biggest hopes and dreams for Lilly would 
be that she can dance.

1632.30.text: She just wants to be on the stage where people can see her.

1634.81.text: She's so confidence about who she is.

1638.09.text: (Lucy) Floating arms like in Swan Lake.

1641.06.text:
(Sharee) It may take her a bit longer, and it may not be 
completely be like being a ballerina.

1646.24.text: (Pete) She might be the first double amputee ballerina.

1656.78.text: (Sharee) We talk about her needing to be in her legs, but at the end of whatever day she wants it to be...

1664.65.text: if she doesn't want to be in her legs, that's her call, because she's only going to do what's good for her.

1671.12.text:
What I think is good for her, and what ends up being good for her 
are two completely different things.

1675.81.text:
She will choose what's best for her, and 
if it's her wheels then wheels it is.

1680.48.text: She will make that work, she will always find a way to make that work.
